messages.text:
Hi folks,

Not sure if I am asking for a right thing but I was wondering if there is any good resource on learning Machine learning with economics connection? I have very less experience of ML stuff. It will be great if there is something which involves Julia, too (I feel, it must be very rare!).

elements.text:
Hi folks,

Not sure if I am asking for a right thing but I was wondering if there is any good resource on learning Machine learning with economics connection? I have very less experience of ML stuff. It will be great if there is something which involves Julia, too (I feel, it must be very rare!).

messages.text: I would start with <https://julia.quantecon.org/index_toc.html|quantecon> if you haven't already, then once you have a basic overview of how things interact, <https://sciml.ai/|sciml> would be the second step.

attachments.title: Table of Contents
attachments.text: This website presents a set of lectures on quantitative economic modeling, designed and written by Jesse Perla, Thomas J. Sargent and John Stachurski.
attachments.fallback: Quantitative Economics with Julia: Table of Contents

elements.text: I would start with
quantecon
if you haven't already, then once you have a basic overview of how things interact,
sciml
would be the second step.

elements.text: HJBs?

messages.text: <@U7Z4938R3> has ideas :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: has ideas

messages.text: I think you should only do this stuff with a particular application in mind.  For most of the things that economists (at least macro and finance) do things just don't fit into the existing frameworks... Even the toy problems aren't written up.  So I would focus on the economic problem ffirst and see how you would want to solve i.

elements.text: I think you should only do this stuff with a particular application in mind.  For most of the things that economists (at least macro and finance) do things just don't fit into the existing frameworks... Even the toy problems aren't written up.  So I would focus on the economic problem ffirst and see how you would want to solve i.

messages.text: But keep in mind that many things in economics are stationary problems and/or infinite horizon which changes the techniques you need.  Similarly, stofhastic vs. deterministic require very different techniques

elements.text: But keep in mind that many things in economics are stationary problems and/or infinite horizon which changes the techniques you need.  Similarly, stofhastic vs. deterministic require very different techniques

messages.text:
metrics professor introducing julia to class

1. Thought that indentation was a requirement, introduced it like python
2. Stopped using Julia at 0.7 because the syntax he was working with changed too much, in particular the optim toolbox
3. Emphasized the lack of economics packages compared to R
4. Has heard from people in IO that a number of people in the field had tried julia earlier on but abandoned it due to syntax changing.
5. Felt like Julia hadn't lived up to expectations as being as fast as C++
6. Writes in R and uses Rccp for fast code usually

Valid comments, except for indentation, I guess. Hopefully we more people realize that the base language is stable and major packages are not going to change, like Optim and JuMP.

messages.text: I think the optim toolbox here is JuMP actually

elements.text: I think the optim toolbox here is JuMP actually

messages.text: JuMP changed a lot around the v1.0 release. They did create a lot of material to migrate and were careful to deprecate though

elements.text: JuMP changed a lot around the v1.0 release. They did create a lot of material to migrate and were careful to deprecate though

messages.text: wait I've been using Optim for all my optimization because I don't have a need for a DSL. I thought JuMP was really for when you want a DSL?

elements.text: wait I've been using Optim for all my optimization because I don't have a need for a DSL. I thought JuMP was really for when you want a DSL?

messages.text: I don't want to say something stupid here... because I'm not a JuMP developer or user. But JuMP is a modeling language for optimization/mathematical programming. It is itself solver-agnostic. You could use Optim as a backend for some of it if you really wanted. It allows you to write up your program and get derivatives efficiently for things like large sparse problems. It has support for non-linear optimization, but as far as I've understood it shines in the more structured problem classes such as: linear, quadratic, mixed-integer, second order conic, ... programming. I'm not sure if it does things like rewriting things into conic constraints automatically?

elements.text: I don't want to say something stupid here... because I'm not a JuMP developer or user. But JuMP is a modeling language for optimization/mathematical programming. It is itself solver-agnostic. You could use Optim as a backend for some of it if you really wanted. It allows you to write up your program and get derivatives efficiently for things like large sparse problems. It has support for non-linear optimization, but as far as I've understood it shines in the more structured problem classes such as: linear, quadratic, mixed-integer, second order conic, ... programming. I'm not sure if it does things like rewriting things into conic constraints automatically?

messages.text: I'd say that's essentially the case. Solver agnostic is the big point here, one interface to multiple disparate apis. Its non-linear capabilities are not stellar however, which is one of the reasons GalacticOptim is in development - attempting to do something similar in the NL space.

Its non-linear capabilities are not stellar however, which is one of the reasons GalacticOptim is in development - attempting to do something similar in the NL space.

messages.text: Sort of. I am working for Julia Computing full-time on <http://Pumas.ai|Pumas.ai> projects and products and we use Optim.jl a lot. So if there are any issues you can be quite sure they'll be fixed (subject to my time constraint not being violated of course :slightly_smiling_face: ) and I am also almost done with a full rewrite of the internals which you can find in NLSolvers.jl (it's registered already). Eventually, Optim will call the code that exists in that package. It should have better support for things such as GPU programming and special array (StaticArrays for example) and number types.  It's fun getting your gradient norm down to 1e-200 with DoubleFloats.jl for example :smile:

messages.text:
Question for you guys <@U7X7BLQSE> and <@U6CJRSR63> (and maybe <@U7Z4938R3>) -- have you guys ever used JuMP with a simulated MoM type of setup?

More specifically, suppose that rather than using (e.g.) logit shares, you wanted to simulate individual decisions (choosing the highest utility option from a menu given a simulated epsilon draw) to compute an objective function, but still wanted to use an MPEC approach to make sure things are in equilibrium (e.g. demand as given by the number of ppl who choose a given choice matches supply). Would you go straight for Optim and try to impose penalties on breaking the equality constraints, or would you try to get this to work with JuMP through a custom function?

elements.text: Question for you guys
and
(and maybe

) -- have you guys ever used JuMP with a simulated MoM type of setup?

More specifically, suppose that rather than using (e.g.) logit shares, you wanted to simulate individual decisions (choosing the highest utility option from a menu given a simulated epsilon draw) to compute an objective function, but still wanted to use an MPEC approach to make sure things are in equilibrium (e.g. demand as given by the number of ppl who choose a given choice matches supply). Would you go straight for Optim and try to impose penalties on breaking the equality constraints, or would you try to get this to work with JuMP through a custom function?

messages.text: Jump is a scalar DSL that goes on top of optimizers. And I think a very good one. But it is just not designed for vector oriented models or custom functions. If you are doing something that requires a serious optimizer and your functions aren't clean scalar based, etc I would consider just using knitro or something like that directly from Julia.

elements.text: Jump is a scalar DSL that goes on top of optimizers. And I think a very good one. But it is just not designed for vector oriented models or custom functions. If you are doing something that requires a serious optimizer and your functions aren't clean scalar based, etc I would consider just using knitro or something like that directly from Julia.

messages.text: been mulling over doing SMM with MPEC a long time for exactly the reasons you mention. unfortunately I had to conclude that it’s less straight forward than I hoped. the problem is the _simulation_ part. The fact that you simulate your moments (so each time they are different, hence the moment function has a different gradient wrt each) is an issue. it depends on your use case of course. My PhD colleague yelmer ypma really nailed it in his thesis I think: <https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/18454112.pdf> (your case: page 29)

messages.text: There are lots of Julia packages that seem well suited to noisy optimisation (as in SMM) including Optim (with simulated annealing), BlackBoxOptim, GalacticOptim, Surrogates, SurrogateModelOptim, GaussianProcesses. If you have a large vector of prices, iterating over the price vector with the update a function of excess demand seems to work well in a lot of applications (example here <https://s3.amazonaws.com/real.stlouisfed.org/wp/2017/2017-005.pdf> ), rather than using penalty/barrier functions.

), rather than using penalty/barrier functions.

messages.text:
Oh sorry, <@U91Q3595Y> one more: for things where the Jacobian is important.. Eg anything like constrained optimization, systems of equations, mpec, implicit solutions to differential equations, mcp,... The first order concern is always using the best algorithm, but after that Jacobian sparsity is probably the next most important.

For example, if the sparsity structure is tridiagonal you only need to evaluate 3 directional derivatives rather than one for each dimension. <https://github.com/JuliaDiff/SparseDiffTools.jl|https://github.com/JuliaDiff/SparseDiffTools.jl> provides tools for that.

This can work with both auto differentiation and finite differences... So if your function is a pain to use AD on, then finite differences might be just as good in speed (but not accuracy)

elements.text: Oh sorry,

one more: for things where the Jacobian is important.. Eg anything like constrained optimization, systems of equations, mpec, implicit solutions to differential equations, mcp,... The first order concern is always using the best algorithm, but after that Jacobian sparsity is probably the next most important.

For example, if the sparsity structure is tridiagonal you only need to evaluate 3 directional derivatives rather than one for each dimension.
https://github.com/JuliaDiff/SparseDiffTools.jl

provides tools for that.

This can work with both auto differentiation and finite differences... So if your function is a pain to use AD on, then finite differences might be just as good in speed (but not accuracy)
